The only challenge is keeping the humidity up when I obsessively open it 1000 times a day. 

If you comment “𝔹𝔸𝔾𝔾𝔼𝔹𝕆” I’ll share every single thing I used to customize this glass cabinet (shelves, lights, smart timers, the works). 

I also just realized it’s been a year since I started sharing my home/ motherhood/ plant life and this emergency house move provided the perfect opportunity to set up and reintroduce my IKEA Greenhouse Cabinet. 

A fun project that took hours of research, but worth it in my opinion. 

Plant parenting can be as chill or as extra as you want. Which end of the spectrum are you 🚁?

Comment “GREENHOUSE” and I can send you the full setup 🤌

Full tutorial coming soon as well that will walk you through all these steps so stay tuned ✌️

This mini greenhouse used to house all of my baby Alocasias that I got as starter plugs, but they outgrew the cabinet in a few short months. This Modern Aqua Akerbar Pegboard set was a GENIUS solution because I was able to reorganize and strategically put in more propagations and some baby Hoyas. Because the entire back is a pegboard, the accessories I can add are limitless! The set also comes with hardware to add a grow light PERFECTLY and seamlessly onto the roof of the cabinet. I also added weatherstripping to hold in the humidity, which usually sits at about 75-85%. 

If you haven’t checked out @modernaqua ‘s goodies, be sure to. Their plant products and accessories for greenhouses are top notch when it comes to aesthetics 🤌🤌🤌(“MICHELLE5” is a special c0-d3 you can use) 

NOW SHOULD I GET ANOTHER ONE 😅

Now I need a trap to keep my kids in bed 🫠

If you comment “TRAP” I’ll be happy to share this extremely effective UV bug trap with an exclusive dïs-cöu.ñt (MICHELLE10) from @shieldecktraps (also Iinked on my 📄). There’s free delivery too 🚚

I’ve never been a fan of those yellow sticky traps ESPECIALLY when the last one ripped off one of my leaves AND got stuck to my hair with bugs on them 🤢. This was honestly soooo much more effective and discrete. The trap is intended for indoor use so when using outdoors, I made sure it wasn’t exposed to anywhere where there would be moisture and I brought it in as soon as movie night ended.

The BEST feature though is there is NO ZAPPING sound because the light attracts the bugs to the sticky paper. It’s silent, chemical-free, and completely safe around my kids and plants and I don’t need to worry about it getting stuck on me like the yellow traps ☠️ 

Who here has been personally victimized by the yellow sticky traps or bugs in general 😂🙋🏻‍♀️
.
.
.
.
.
.

The separated twin didn’t want the glow-up 🙈

If you comment “GLOWUP” I’ll share everything I used for this Monstera repot (soil, root crack, gnat fairy dust, etc). To help you get the details quicker, I use an automated messaging service so just make sure you type in the keyword exactly 🙌 (all Iinked on my 📄 too). 

Monsteras want a chunky aroid mix that drains quickly, and I swear the Myco root crack works wonders. The smaller, second plant will just need a few more weeks in the ICU with boosted humidity and lots of light to recover, but the more established twin is doing GREAT 🤌. 

My friend also dropped off a Monstera Thai Constellation to repot so stay tuned for that 🫶 because even though these are both Monsteras, my care for Thai Cons is a little different. 

Do you have plant doctor friends too 🌱

Waiting for the day for these to become glorious and huge 🌱

Can you believe these @bwhplantco Thai Cons are only $42?!?!

If you comment “TC” I’ll share a dîs-c0.unt code for these Thai Cons along with all the repotting goodies I used (the super duper chunky orchid mix, root crack, fertilizer) ✌️

I’m shocked these plants are still in stock, but also love that these rare plants are FINALLY accessible to everyone. Thai cons are susceptible to root rot so watering only when dry in a very airy, well-draining mix is key, but also I’m glad I can have actual backups because when I rotted my first one, it took months to recover and I questioned everything about my plant care routine. Alas, that’s all part of the learning process 🙃. 

Now what I don’t need backups of are my Pothos. Someone help my 10000 propagations ☠️. 

What do you have backups of?

If you comment “EASY” I’ll share these self-watering plants that are on sale for Labor Day through Sept 4 using my c0d.è “10OFFMICHELLE”. The Labor Day collection is limited and all plants ship free with a 90-day guarantee 🤌. As a bonus, I’ll also share the things I use for my new plant care routine! (All Iinked on my 📄). 

Sometimes self-watering pots get a bad rap for rotting plants, but I’ve honestly NEVER had that issue for any of my EasyPlants. The trick is to not always have the reservoir constantly filled. I wait until the reservoir empties out AND the soil dries out. For most of my plants, it comes out to about once a month. I’ve even re-used these pots with completely different plants.

But what do I do about my Monstera that is taking over my house 🙈 Would you just let it expand forever or should I chop and separate it?
.

What is your baseline attitude toward strangers 😶

When I was pregnant - like FULL-ON preggo, I was doing my daily walk at Target (because is there any other activity that brings women more joy when you’re on maternity leave?) when some guy approached me and handed me a note and walked away. Inside said note was his name and phone number. Target shopping mood installed ruined 😑. 

Fast forward to a few weeks ago, as I was walking down an aisle, I heard someone saying “Excuse me! Excuse me!” I assumed it wasn’t toward me and I continued walking. Then 5 min later in a different aisle I heard it AGAIN. I turned around and a woman ran up to me and said, “I can sense your energy. It’s so strong. Let me give you my number. You must call me to read your fortune.”

Moral of the story: Target is no longer safe for peaceful, leisurely strolls and it’s SO SAD. 

Pictured: My two variegated Frydeks. The one on the left was grown from a corm and from a lovely friend. The one on the right I just got the other week and stay tuned for a special announcement in the next few weeks 🙃. This plant is definitely a mood lifter so my Target walks have been replaced by obsessively staring at these in my greenhouse. My only interruptions are from my kids, which I welcome any day over unsolicited interruptions from strangers. 

What is your solo, leisurely activity of choice? 🙃
.
.
.
.
.

Just another day in my comments section 💅

If you comment “TROLLME” (one word), I’d be happy to share all these plant torturing goodies such as the moss pole, root crâck, and plant probiotics for my new Philodendron Sodiroi from @caliplantcollc

💈I love how big the leaves got on my Philodendron Majestic, and the Sodiroi is a parent plant, so I’m excited to see how this will do on a moss pole. If you’ve never ventured into the world of moss poles, I highly recommend it because it’s so satisfying to see plants attach to them and take off. It’s next level of plant parenting. 

🧚I’ve been using the root cráck for every plant repot and so far none of my plants have exhibited typical signs repotting stress even when I switched substrates (like from soil to LECA). 

☀️The plant probiotics are the cherry on top of everything to give my plants some added micronutrients and prevent any fungal diseases. They can be used as a foliar spray too (PERFECT for air plants) 

But, you don’t need to take my word for it. This is all based on my personal research and what works for me and my plants in my environment. ☠️

Torture any plants lately? 😂
.

I think he likes it, don’t you? 😇

If you comment “MOTHERDM” (ONE word), I’ll send you this Mother PlantSpectrum light along with their Mother Plant Library where you can see how much light different plants require, the recommended distance between a light and plant, and how long to keep grow lights on for. (Ships worldwide ✈️ and also Iinked on my 📃). 

Light is often the most underestimated factor when talking about plant growth! Here are the features of this highly aesthetic, yet highly effective light that’s used both in home and in professional indoor farms:

💡Waterproof and designed to work in humid environments including inside greenhouses
💡 Designed to last forever. The life expectancy of an LED chip is about 8 years, which means you need to buy a new grow light again. PlantSpectrum’s inner LED board is replaceable so you can use this light forever and help contribute to less production waste
💡 PAR is over 92% to boost any type of plant’s growth (PAR is the range of wavelengths that directly contributes to plant growth and development). 
💡All parts are corrosion and wear-resistant with its 100% recycled aluminum body designed for maximum lifespan of the module. No glue or paint is used anywhere. 

TL;DR: It’s a legit grow light setup that is designed to last forever and is proven to be highly effective for plant growth 🌱.

I just love how perfect these lights ended up working for my climbing plants on moss poles. With winter coming, this is the perfect way to ensure my plants will grow year-round.

Do you have plants that are begging for more light ☀️?

If you comment “MOSSDM” (ONE WORD) I’ll share everything I used to grow this 4 baby leaf Philodendron Splendid from @prettyingreenplants into the 5ft tree she is today (also Iinked on my 📃). 

These DIY moss poles from @growthiccly are incredibly easy to put together. Start to finish is 5 minutes (although I do have pre-moistened moss I store in a ziplock bag because I’m a psycho that prepares for moss emergencies). 

Ultimate plan: Chop the top third of the plant and make that the new BOTTOM. Take the mid-cut and also make that the new bottom so I have two vines growing up for a fuller look. The rooted bottom cut I’ll gift to a friend. 

I know I need to calm down on climbing Philodendron, but I literally cannot stop. 

What would you do? Let it keep climbing or chop?

And I never misplaced my watering can again 👌

If you comment “DRIP” I’ll share this LIFE CHANGING watering pump along with the nutrients and gnat-unaliver ☠️. 

I keep this jug in a dark, cool location (for me, my bathroom) and it’s made my life so much more efficient. I also leave the water out for at least 24 hours for the chlorine to dissipate.

The nutrient solution I use for both soil and semihydroponics and the gnat unaliver contains the same active ingredient as mosquito bits, but without the whole process of soaking and removing bits 🤌

The other weekend I took my kids (soon to be 2 and soon to be 5) to the Hot Wheels monster truck show. I have never been to one and never imagined I would ever attend one, but I knew something was up when we were the only fools in line without ear muffs. 

As soon as we entered the arena I could feel the sound vibrate into my soul ☠️ and we spent more money on Hot Wheel-branded ear muffs than the actual tickets, but 100% necessary. 

One of the truck drivers was also a woman and now I feel like my first gen Asian parents gate-kept the potential career opportunity to be a monster truck driver because this show was FREAKING AWESOME and why wouldn’t any little girl want to drive a glow in the dark truck that smashes cars?!? 

Now the world will never know what I could have been 😙

So alas, pictured is my Pothos propagation that I finally planted and put on a trellis. When I mentioned I compost my Pothos cuttings the other week, the internet had a field day in my comments section, but honestly, these are such prolific growers that I cannot keep up with propagating. I’ve gifted countless plants to friends and public groups and I don’t want to sell. At some point, I need to end the cycle of propagation so that this hobby continues to remain enjoyable and allow me to focus my time and energy on other things like ….researching how to career change into a monster truck driver 🤓

WHAT CAREER DID YOUR PARENTS GATE KEEP FROM YOU 😝
.
.
.
.
.

If you comment “MOSSY” I’ll be happy to share everything you need to make a moss pole (the pole, moss, nutrients, dripping thingy, etc…)

I was intimated with moss poles at first, but these are so easy to make and extend. Here are my top tips for making a moss pole for your climbing plants ⬇️

1. Start when plants are young. It’s easier to train a younger plant than a mature one. 

2. Use plastic wrap to keep the nodes attached to the moist moss. Once it roots, you can remove the wrap. 

3. Add nutrients to the moss! Most of the plant roots are in the moss (not the soil) so I make sure to fertilize the moss pole like I do soil. 

4. When watering, use the slow-drip method becasue dry moss is hydrophobic so if you flood the moss with water, it will just run straight through. Slow dripping will ensure even saturation. 

5. If the soil isn’t ready to be watered, only use enough water to saturate the pole - not the soil. 

6. Use Yucca extract! It’s great at rehydrating moss (comment for 🔗)

I also get asked which plants are easy to start on moss poles - my vote is a Pothos since they’re such fast growers and very common to find.

If you comment “FLF”, I’ll send you the details on my care for Fiddle Leaf Figs (which applies to houseplants in general) including this sleek Sol-Leaf grow light, which has been so helpful in ensuring this plant gets enough light especially with the winter months coming. (Also Iinked on my 📄 with an exclusive dìsc0unt) 

Here are some💡features:

-4 Light Spectrum Profiles (seed, grow, bloom, and “all”) 
-4 levels of brightness 
-8 timer modes
-Waterproof design 
-Optical lens to concentrate the light on the plants 

This Fiddle Leaf Fig was totally fine until I moved houses, and it was not satisfied in its new location and dropped so many leaves. I learned the hard way that FLFs like a LOT more light than you would think and so without prime real estate next to a bright window, this grow light was much needed. 

In my experience, Fiddles also prefer a short drying period between waterings and the reason why I do both bottom and top watering is because water follows the path of least resistance. If I only water from the top, water will flow through the channels in the soil and out the drainage holes immediately leaving much of the soil still dry. By bottom watering, the entire soil gets saturated. This is another reason why bright light is required. If the plant doesn’t get enough light to process the water, the plant will just be sitting in moist soil for longer, which is also not good. 

I feel like Fiddles were the quintessential plant of the millennial household at one point until people realized how fickle they can be. However, once you figure out its ideal light and watering needs, these can be no-fuss. 

Where are all my Fiddle millennials at? And if you’re not a millennial, DO YOU HAVE ONE?!

If you comment “RAINPOINT” (ONE WORD), I’ll share all the details about this nifty drip irrigation system I use to keep my plants watered when I’m away (including what I put into my water to prevent fungus gnats!) - this is also Iinked on my 📄. 

Prepping my houseplants for a vacation has always been a chore that takes most of the day, but I’ve been really pleased with how well this irrigation system works. 

It’s important to note that I don’t water my plants off a schedule. However, I know my plants’ drying pattern well enough now to generally know when they need to be watered. This pattern changes by the season. During the winter with shorter days, it takes longer for plants to use up all the water in the soil via photosynthesis so plants can go longer between waterings. Once you observe your plants long enough, you’ll learn this pattern. This is how I know my plants won’t be over or underwatered via this irrigation system. I just gather all the plants I know aren’t ready to be watered before I leave, but will need to be watered while I’m gone, and set the date/time for when I’ll activate the irrigation. 

My next project is to rig this to keep my MOSS POLES moist when I’m away because these need the most frequent watering. I can also see this being super handy for garden beds, propagations, and seedlings that need to be consistently moist.

If you comment “NEWPLANT” (ONE WORD), I’ll share my homemade insecticidal spray concoction that I use on 100% of my plants. I’ll also include a special d I s c o u n t on how you can get this beautiful Calathea White Fusion and Stromanthe Trio Star for about $13-16! Such a deal 🤌

I’m also aware the official pronunciation is ka·luh·thee·uh, but it’s one of those things where my brain REFUSES to make my mouth say these syllables correctly. My track record with Calatheas is not great because these plants prefer consistent moisture with distilled water and I’m a chronic underwriter and I refuse to buy distilled water. Soooo I’ve been testing out a workaround that I’ll share the results of soon. 

As for the homemade insecticidal spray, I use this about every two weeks for maintenance / cleaning leaves. For active infestations, I use this every 2-3 days and don’t wipe down the leaves afterward. Do keep plants out of direct light after use because it is oil-based. 

The yucca extract is a newer ingredient I added to my spray concoction. It works as a natural pest repellent and lowers the surface tension of the water in the spray, allowing the insecticide to spread flat over the surface of the leaf to coat it more effectively to suffocate any bugs! 

Did anyone else freak out from all the DOTS on the close-up of the leaves 😳. I swear this microscope is a blessing and a curse.

If you comment “PLANTAPP” (ONE WORD), I can share details on this Plant ID & Disease Identifier app (also Iinked on my 📄). There are free and paid features and right now, the paid features are 50% off for the yearly subscription. 

CAUTION
Not all plant apps are the same. There are ones out there that give odd “hacks” to treat plants that are just not founded in science (eg watering with coffee and even period blood 🤮). This app is not one of them. I spent a good amount of time testing out every feature and looking through the various treatment plants and everything has aligned with my experience in addressing a number of plant issues like pests, overwatering, and even sunburn. 

FEATURES
Beyond the plant identification and disease diagnosis/treatment tools, the most practical feature is probably the Task & Reminders because it allows you to set reminders for when to water, fertilize, and rotate your plants. I’ll be a broken record when I say, I do not water off of a schedule. How quickly the soil dries out depends on the season, humidity, light levels, etc. HOWEVER, once you generally know how quickly YOUR plants dry out in YOUR environment, you can set reminders via an app, which is helpful!

COOL AI TOOL
There is an AI Botanist tool that I’ll demonstrate in my Stories that is really nifty! 

TL;DR
I find the features on this app to be practical and useful. The treatment and care advice is sound 👌. This one’s a keeper!

The cloning paste is super impressive. You can use it on nearly any plant by rubbing the paste on the inactive growth points of the plant. Pretty nifty. Taking bets on whether this tree makes a comeback ☠️

Comment “FICUSME” (ONE word) and I’ll share what I used to repot and force-clone the leaves on this Ficus Altissima (including the root cráck, soil, and cloning paste). Also Iinked on my 📄. 

Can you believe this went from LUSH to SCARECROW status so quickly 😒. I don’t know what it is about Ficuses, but in my experience, they absolutely hate being rootbound. When my other Ficus did this, repotting into a larger pot did the trick and the tree made a full comeback - but for that tree, it didn’t lose 99% of its leaves 🙈 so we’ll see. 

The cloning paste was super successful on my string of hearts so I am experimenting with it here before this tree makes its journey into becoming toilet paper. Because Ficus nodes can be kind of woody, I did score the nodes a bit before applying the paste. 

What do you think? Will it survive 😩? Who also DESPISES unpacking after a long trip 🙃?

Full birthing process of these frydek quintuplet corms is up on my Y0utǔbe now! 

Comment “PREGGO” and I’ll share everything you need to know about propagating Alocasias corms. 

I’ll never understand the fertility of Alocasias. I’ve had some Alos for years that popped out 1-2 corms ever and I have a plantet that was only a corm a few months ago that is already growing its own corms. 

This Frydek is not a variegaed mama, but she’s still a beauty nonetheless. The mother for some reason cannot handle more than two leaves, but clearly her babies are thriving. 

My favorite way to propagate these is in aquatic soil, but I’ve also done water and moss successfully. 

Up next: my VARIEGATED frydek is also preggo and her corms are HUGE. 

I definitely am not keeping 5 baby frydeks. I’ll likely give them away to my subscriber group on fàcebook once they sprout leaves ✌️

Why do I keep buying these drama queens ☠️. 

Comment “DRIP” and I’ll share my water recipe and nifty water pump. This includes the de-chlorinating solution, anti-gnat drops, and fertilizer that’s good for soil and soilless mediums. I’ve PERFECTED this recipe over the last year and I love it! 

I used to leave water out overnight to allow the chlorine to evaporate, but I learned that tap water also contains chloramine, which does NOT evaporate, so this new solution I add to my water takes care of all of that. I’ve been slowly experimenting with this over multiple waterings for over a month now and I haven’t seen the telltale signs of crispy edges on any of my calatheas (minus the ☠️ one in the bathroom), so I’m comfortable sharing this as part of my watering routine now 🤌. 

Now if you use tap water across all your plants and they’re fine, then by all means, don’t fix what’s isn’t broken. I’m sharing what works for me in my environment 🥰. 

These Calatheas and my complete care for them will be featured in an upcoming Y0utübe so stay tuned 👀

Raise your hand if you have one of these drama queens 🙋🏻‍♀️
